- - 1. One or both of the following:
- - - a. Cracks within 125 cm of the soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the soil surface; or
- - - b. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower; and
- - 2. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 3. A thermic, mesic, or frigid soil temperature regime and an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on xeric.
--------------------------
Ustertic Torriorthents
LECE. Other Torriorthents that have:
- - 1. One or both of the following:
- - - a. Cracks within 125 cm of the soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the soil surface; or
- - - b. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower; and
- - 2. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 3. An aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on ustic.
--------------------------
Vertic Torriorthents
LECF. Other Torriorthents that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Anthraltic Torriorthents
LECG. Other Torriorthents that have 50 cm or more of human-altered material.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Torriorthents
LECH. Other Torriorthents that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Aquic Torriorthents
LECI. Other Torriorthents that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Torriorthents
LECJ. Other Torriorthents that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 150 cm of the soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Duric Torriorthents
LECK. Other Torriorthents that have a horizon within 100 cm of the soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Ustic Torriorthents
LECL. Other Torriorthents that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 2. A hyperthermic, thermic, mesic, frigid, or iso soil temperature regime and an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on ustic.
--------------------------
Xeric Torriorthents
LECM. Other Torriorthents that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 2. A thermic, mesic, or frigid soil temperature regime and an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on xeric.
--------------------------
Typic Torriorthents
LECN. Other Torriorthents.
--------------------------
Lithic Udorthents
LEFA. Udorthents that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthrodensic Sodic Udorthents
LEFB. Other Udorthents that have both of the following:
- - 1. A densic contact due to mechanical compaction in more than 90 percent of the pedon (measured laterally) within 100 cm of the soil surface; and
- - 2. An exchangeable sodium percentage of 15 or more (or a sodium adsorption ratio of 13 or more) in a horizon at least 25 cm thick within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthrodensic Udorthents
LEFC. Other Udorthents that have a densic contact due to mechanical compaction in more than 90 percent of the pedon (measured laterally) within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthroportic Udorthents
LEFD. Other Udorthents that have 50 cm or more of human-transported material.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Udorthents
LEFE. Other Udorthents that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Aquic Udorthents
LEFF. Other Udorthents that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Udorthents
LEFG. Other Udorthents that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Vermic Udorthents
LEFH. Other Udorthents that have 50 percent or more (by volume) wormholes, wormcasts, and filled animal burrows between either the Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Udorthents
LEFI. Other Udorthents.
--------------------------
Aridic Lithic Ustorthents
LEEA. Ustorthents that have both:
- - 1. A lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. When neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, one of the following:
- - - a. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for four-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - b. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for six-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - c. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is moist in some or all parts for less than 90 consecutive days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC.
--------------------------
Lithic Ustorthents
LEEB. Other Ustorthents that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Torrertic Ustorthents
LEEC. Other Ustorthents that have both:
- - 1. One or both of the following:
- - - a. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - - b. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower; and
- - 2. When neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, one of the following:
- - - a. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for four-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - b. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for six-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - c. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is moist in some or all parts for less than 90 consecutive days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC.
--------------------------
Vertic Ustorthents
LEED. Other Ustorthents that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Anthraquic Ustorthents
LEEE. Other Ustorthents that have anthraquic conditions.
--------------------------
Anthrodensic Ustorthents
LEEF. Other Ustorthents that have a densic contact due to mechanical compaction in more than 90 percent of the pedon (measured laterally) within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthroportic Ustorthents
LEEG. Other Ustorthents that have 50 cm or more of human-transported material.
--------------------------
Aquic Ustorthents
LEEH. Other Ustorthents that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Ustorthents
LEEI. Other Ustorthents that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Durinodic Ustorthents
LEEJ. Other Ustorthents that have a horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Vitritorrandic Ustorthents
LEEK. Other Ustorthents that have both:
- - 1. When neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, one of the following:
- - - a. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for four-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - b. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for six-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - - c. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is moist in some or all parts for less than 90 consecutive days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - - a. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - b. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Ustorthents
LEEL. Other Ustorthents that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Aridic Ustorthents
LEEM. Other Ustorthents that, when neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, have one of the following:
- - 1. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for four-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 2. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for six-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 3. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is moist in some or all parts for less than 90 consecutive days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC.
--------------------------
Udic Ustorthents
LEEN. Other Ustorthents that, when neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, have one of the following:
- - 1. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some or all parts for less than 105 cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 2. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for less than four-tenths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 3. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some or all parts for less than 120 cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC.
--------------------------
Vermic Ustorthents
LEEO. Other Ustorthents that have 50 percent or more (by volume) wormholes, wormcasts, and filled animal burrows between either the Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Ustorthents
LEEP. Other Ustorthents.
--------------------------
Lithic Xerorthents
LEDA. Xerorthents that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthraltic Sodic Xerorthents
LEDB. Other Xerorthents that have both of the following:
- - 1. 50 cm or more of human-altered material; and
- - 2. An exchangeable sodium percentage of 15 or more (or a sodium adsorption ratio of 13 or more) in a horizon at least 25 cm thick within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Anthraltic Xerorthents
LEDC. Other Xerorthents that have 50 cm or more of human-altered material.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Xerorthents
LEDD. Other Xerorthents that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Aquic Xerorthents
LEDE. Other Xerorthents that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Xerorthents
LEDF. Other Xerorthents that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Durinodic Xerorthents
LEDG. Other Xerorthents that have a horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Dystric Xerorthents
LEDH. Other Xerorthents that have a base saturation (by NH4OAc) of less than 60 percent in all horizons at a depth between 25 and 75 cm below the mineral soil surface or in the horizon directly above a root-limiting layer (defined in chapter 17) that is at a shallower depth.
--------------------------
Typic Xerorthents
LEDI. Other Xerorthents.
--------------------------
Cryopsamments
LCA. Psamments that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Torripsamments
LCB. Other Psamments that have an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Quartzipsamments
LCC. Other Psamments that have, in the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction within the particle-size control section, a total of more than 90 percent (by weighted average) resistant minerals.
--------------------------
Ustipsamments
LCD. Other Psamments that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xeropsamments
LCE. Other Psamments that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Udipsamments
LCF. Other Psamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryopsamments
LCAA. Cryopsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquic Cryopsamments
LCAB. Other Cryopsamments that have, in one or more horizons within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Cryopsamments
LCAC. Other Cryopsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Cryopsamments
LCAD. Other Cryopsamments that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction containing 5 percent or more volcanic glass, and [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is 30 or more.
--------------------------
Spodic Cryopsamments
LCAE. Other Cryopsamments that have a horizon 5 cm or more thick that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Lamellic Cryopsamments
LCAF. Other Cryopsamments that have lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Cryopsamments
LCAG. Other Cryopsamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Quartzipsamments
LCCA. Quartzipsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquodic Quartzipsamments
LCCB. Other Quartzipsamments that have both:
- - 1. In one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. A horizon, 5 cm or more thick, either below an Ap horizon or at a depth of 18 cm or more from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, that has one or more of the following:
- - - a. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - - b. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - - c. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Aquic Quartzipsamments
LCCC. Other Quartzipsamments that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Quartzipsamments
LCCD. Other Quartzipsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Ustoxic Quartzipsamments
LCCE. Other Quartzipsamments that meet all of the following:
- - 1. Have an ustic soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Have a clay fraction with a CEC of 16 cmol(+) or less per kg clay (by 1N NH4OAc pH 7); and
- - 3. The sum of the weighted average silt plus 2 times the weighted average clay (both by weight) is more than 5.
--------------------------
Udoxic Quartzipsamments
LCCF. Other Quartzipsamments that meet all of the following:
- - 1. Have a udic soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Have a clay fraction with a CEC of 16 cmol(+) or less per kg clay (by 1N NH4OAc pH 7); and
- - 3. The sum of the weighted average silt plus 2 times the weighted average clay (both by weight) is more than 5.
--------------------------
Plinthic Quartzipsamments
LCCG. Other Quartzipsamments that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Lamellic Ustic Quartzipsamments
LCCH. Other Quartzipsamments that have both:
- - 1. Lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. An ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Lamellic Quartzipsamments
LCCI. Other Quartzipsamments that have lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Ustic Quartzipsamments
LCCJ. Other Quartzipsamments that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xeric Quartzipsamments
LCCK. Other Quartzipsamments that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Spodic Quartzipsamments
LCCL. Other Quartzipsamments that have a horizon, 5 cm or more thick, either below an Ap horizon or at a depth of 18 cm or more from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Typic Quartzipsamments
LCCM. Other Quartzipsamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Torripsamments
LCBA. Torripsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Torripsamments
LCBB. Other Torripsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Torripsamments
LCBC. Other Torripsamments that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction containing 5 percent or more volcanic glass, and [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is 30 or more.
--------------------------
Haploduridic Torripsamments
LCBD. Other Torripsamments that have a horizon within 100 cm of the soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Ustic Torripsamments
LCBE. Other Torripsamments that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 2. An aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on ustic.
--------------------------
Xeric Torripsamments
LCBF. Other Torripsamments that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for less than three-fourths of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is 5 oC or higher; and
- - 2. A thermic, mesic, or frigid soil temperature regime and an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime that borders on xeric.
--------------------------
Rhodic Torripsamments
LCBG. Other Torripsamments that have, in all horizons from a depth of 25 to 100 cm, more than 50 percent colors that have all of the following:
- - 1. Hue of 2.5YR or redder; and
- - 2. A color value, moist, of 3 or less; and
- - 3. A dry value no more than 1 unit higher than the moist value.
--------------------------
Typic Torripsamments
LCBH. Other Torripsamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Udipsamments
LCFA. Udipsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquic Udipsamments
LCFB. Other Udipsamments that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Udipsamments
LCFC. Other Udipsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Spodic Udipsamments
LCFD. Other Udipsamments that have a horizon, 5 cm or more thick, either below an Ap horizon or at a depth of 18 cm or more from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Lamellic Udipsamments
LCFE. Other Udipsamments that have lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Haploplaggic Udipsamments
LCFF. Other Udipsamments that have a surface horizon between 25 and 50 cm thick that meets all of the requirements for a plaggen epipedon except thickness.
--------------------------
Typic Udipsamments
LCFG. Other Udipsamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Ustipsamments
LCDA. Ustipsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquic Ustipsamments
LCDB. Other Ustipsamments that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Ustipsamments
LCDC. Other Ustipsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Aridic Ustipsamments
LCDD. Other Ustipsamments that, when neither irrigated nor fallowed to store moisture, have one of the following:
- - 1. A frigid soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in all parts for four-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 2. A mesic or thermic soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is dry in some part for six-tenths or more of the cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 5 oC; or
- - 3. A hyperthermic, isomesic, or warmer iso soil temperature regime and a moisture control section that, in normal years, is moist in some or all parts for less than 180 cumulative days per year when the soil temperature at a depth of 50 cm below the soil surface is higher than 8 oC.
--------------------------
Lamellic Ustipsamments
LCDE. Other Ustipsamments that have lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Rhodic Ustipsamments
LCDF. Other Ustipsamments that have, in all horizons from a depth of 25 to 100 cm, more than 50 percent colors that have all of the following:
- - 1. Hue of 2.5YR or redder; and
- - 2. A color value, moist, of 3 or less; and
- - 3. A dry value no more than 1 unit higher than the moist value.
--------------------------
Typic Ustipsamments
LCDG. Other Ustipsamments.
--------------------------
Lithic Xeropsamments
LCEA. Xeropsamments that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquic Durinodic Xeropsamments
LCEB. Other Xeropsamments that have both:
- - 1. In one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. A horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Aquic Xeropsamments
LCEC. Other Xeropsamments that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Xeropsamments
LCED. Other Xeropsamments that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Xeropsamments
LCEE. Other Xeropsamments that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction containing 5 percent or more volcanic glass, and [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is 30 or more.
--------------------------
Durinodic Xeropsamments
LCEF. Other Xeropsamments that have a horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that is 15 cm or more thick and that either has 20 percent or more (by volume) durinodes or is brittle and has at least a firm rupture-resistance class when moist.
--------------------------
Lamellic Xeropsamments
LCEG. Other Xeropsamments that have lamellae within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Dystric Xeropsamments
LCEH. Other Xeropsamments that have a base saturation (by NH4OAc) of less than 60 percent in all horizons at a depth between 25 and 75 cm below the mineral soil surface or in the horizon directly above a root-limiting layer (defined in chapter 17) that is at a shallower depth.
--------------------------
Typic Xeropsamments
LCEI. Other Xeropsamments.
--------------------------
Frasiwassents
LAA. Wassents that have, in all horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, an electrical conductivity of less than 0.2 dS/m in a 1:5 (soil:water), by volume, supernatant (not extract).
--------------------------
Psammowassents
LAB. Other Wassents that have less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Sulfiwassents
LAC. Other Wassents that have a horizon or horizons with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Hydrowassents
LAD. Other Wassents that have, in all horizons at a depth between 20 and 50 cm below the mineral soil surface, both an n value of more than 0.7 and 8 percent or more clay in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Fluviwassents
LAE. Other Wassents that have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons and one or both of the following:
- - 1. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - 2. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Haplowassents
LAF. Other Wassents.
--------------------------
Sulfic Fluviwassents
LAEA. Fluviwassents that have a horizon or horizons with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Lithic Fluviwassents
LAEB. Other Fluviwassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Thapto-Histic Fluviwassents
LAEC. Other Fluviwassents that have a buried layer of organic soil materials, 20 cm or more thick, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aeric Fluviwassents
LAED. Other Fluviwassents that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons between a depth of 15 and 100 cm from the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Fluviwassents
LAEE. Other Fluviwassents.
--------------------------
Hydric Frasiwassents
LAAA. Frasiwassents that have, in all horizons at a depth between 20 and 50 cm below the mineral soil surface, both an n value of more than 0.7 and 8 percent or more clay in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Lithic Frasiwassents
LAAB. Other Frasiwassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Psammentic Frasiwassents
LAAC. Other Frasiwassents that have less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Thapto-Histic Frasiwassents
LAAD. Other Frasiwassents that have a buried layer of organic soil materials, 20 cm or more thick, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluventic Frasiwassents
LAAE. Other Frasiwassents that have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons and one or both of the following:
- - 1. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - 2. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Frasiwassents
LAAF. Other Frasiwassents that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons between a depth of 15 and 100 cm from the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Frasiwassents
LAAG. Other Frasiwassents.
--------------------------
Sulfic Haplowassents
LAFA. Haplowassents that have a horizon or horizons with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplowassents
LAFB. Other Haplowassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aeric Haplowassents
LAFC. Other Haplowassents that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons between a depth of 15 and 100 cm from the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Haplowassents
LAFD. Other Haplowassents.
--------------------------
Sulfic Hydrowassents
LADA. Hydrowassents that have a horizon or horizons with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Grossic Hydrowassents
LADB. Other Hydrowassents that have, in all horizons at a depth between 20 and 100 cm below the mineral soil surface, both an n value of more than 0.7 and 8 percent or more clay in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Lithic Hydrowassents
LADC. Other Hydrowassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Thapto-Histic Hydrowassents
LADD. Other Hydrowassents that have a buried layer of organic soil materials, 20 cm or more thick, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Hydrowassents
LADE. Other Hydrowassents.
--------------------------
Sulfic Psammowassents
LABA. Psammowassents that have a horizon or horizons with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Lithic Psammowassents
LABB. Other Psammowassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluventic Psammowassents
LABC. Other Psammowassents that have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons and one or both of the following:
- - 1. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - 2. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Psammowassents
LABD. Other Psammowassents that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons between a depth of 15 and 100 cm from the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Psammowassents
LABE. Other Psammowassents.
--------------------------
Lithic Sulfiwassents
LACA. Sulfiwassents that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Haplic Sulfiwassents
LACB. Other Sulfiwassents that have, in some horizons at a depth between 20 and 50 cm below the mineral soil surface, either or both: 1. An n value of 0.7 or less; or
- - 2. Less than 8 percent clay in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Thapto-Histic Sulfiwassents
LACC. Other Sulfiwassents that have a buried layer of organic soil materials, 20 cm or more thick, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluventic Sulfiwassents
LACD. Other Sulfiwassents that have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons and one or both of the following:
- - 1. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - 2. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Sulfiwassents
LACE. Other Sulfiwassents that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons between a depth of 15 and 100 cm from the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfiwassents
LACF. Other Sulfiwassents.
--------------------------
Histels
AA. Gelisols that have organic soil materials that meet one or more of the following:
- - 1. Overlie cindery, fragmental, or pumiceous materials and/or fill their interstices and directly below these materials have either a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact; or
- - 2. When added with the underlying cindery, fragmental, or pumiceous materials, total 40 cm or more between the soil surface and a depth of 50 cm; or
- - 3. Comprise 80 percent or more, by volume, from the soil surface to a depth of 50 cm or to a glacic layer or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Turbels
AB. Other Gelisols that have one or more horizons showing cryoturbation in the form of irregular, broken, or distorted horizon boundaries, involutions, the accumulation of organic matter on top of the permafrost, ice or sand wedges, and oriented rock fragments.
--------------------------
Orthels
AC. Other Gelisols.
--------------------------
Folistels
AAA. Histels that are saturated with water for less than 30 cumulative days during normal years (and are not artificially drained).
--------------------------
Glacistels
AAB. Other Histels that are saturated with water for 30 or more cumulative days during normal years and that have both:
- - 1. A glacic layer within 100 cm of the soil surface; and
- - 2. Less than three-fourths (by volume) Sphagnum fibers in the organic soil material to a depth of 50 cm or to a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fibristels
AAC. Other Histels that have more thickness of fibric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil material to a depth of 50 cm or to a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Hemistels
AAD. Other Histels that have more thickness of hemic soil materials than any other kind of organic soil material to a depth of 50 cm or to a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Sapristels
AAE. Other Histels.
--------------------------
Lithic Fibristels
AACA. Fibristels that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Terric Fibristels
AACB. Other Fibristels that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Fibristels
AACC. Other Fibristels that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of any thickness within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Sphagnic Fibristels
AACD. Other Fibristels in which three-fourths or more (by volume) of the fibric soil materials are derived from Sphagnum to a depth of 50 cm or to a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Fibristels
AACE. Other Fibristels.
--------------------------
Lithic Folistels
AAAA. Folistels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Folistels
AAAB. Other Folistels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Folistels
AAAC. Other Folistels.
--------------------------
Hemic Glacistels
AABA. Glacistels that have more thickness of hemic soil materials than any other kind of organic soil material in the upper 50 cm.
--------------------------
Sapric Glacistels
AABB. Other Glacistels that have more thickness of sapric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil material in the upper 50 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Glacistels
AABC. Other Glacistels.
--------------------------
Lithic Hemistels
AADA. Hemistels that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Terric Hemistels
AADB. Other Hemistels that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Hemistels
AADC. Other Hemistels that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of any thickness within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Hemistels
AADD. Other Hemistels.
--------------------------
Lithic Sapristels
AAEA. Sapristels that have a lithic contact within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Terric Sapristels
AAEB. Other Sapristels that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Sapristels
AAEC. Other Sapristels that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of any thickness within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Sapristels
AAED. Other Sapristels.
--------------------------
Historthels
ACA. Orthels that have a histic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquorthels
ACB. Other Orthels that have, within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Anhyorthels
ACC. Other Orthels that have anhydrous conditions.
--------------------------
Mollorthels
ACD. Other Orthels that have a mollic epipedon.
--------------------------
Umbrorthels
ACE. Other Orthels that have an umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Argiorthels
ACF. Other Orthels that have an argillic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Psammorthels
ACG. Other Orthels that have, below the Ap horizon or below a depth of 25 cm, whichever is deeper, less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Haplorthels
ACH. Other Orthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Anhyorthels
ACCA. Anhyorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Anhyorthels
ACCB. Other Anhyorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Petrogypsic Anhyorthels
ACCC. Other Anhyorthels that have a petrogypsic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Gypsic Anhyorthels
ACCD. Other Anhyorthels that have a gypsic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Nitric Anhyorthels
ACCE. Other Anhyorthels that have both of the following:
- - 1. A horizon 15 cm or more thick that has a nitrate concentration of 118 mmol(-)/L or more in a 1:5 soil:water extract; and
- - 2. The product of horizon thickness (in cm) times nitrate concentration [in mmol(-)/L] is 3,500 or more.
--------------------------
Salic Anhyorthels
ACCF. Other Anhyorthels that have a salic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Calcic Anhyorthels
ACCG. Other Anhyorthels that have a calcic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Anhyorthels
ACCH. Other Anhyorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Aquorthels
ACBA. Aquorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Aquorthels
ACBB. Other Aquorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Sulfuric Aquorthels
ACBC. Other Aquorthels that have a sulfuric horizon or sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Ruptic-Histic Aquorthels
ACBD. Other Aquorthels that have either:
- - 1. Organic soil materials that are discontinuous at the surface; or
- - 2. Organic soil materials at the surface that change in thickness fourfold or more within a pedon.
--------------------------
Andic Aquorthels
ACBE. Other Aquorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Aquorthels
ACBF. Other Aquorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Salic Aquorthels
ACBG. Other Aquorthels that have a salic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Psammentic Aquorthels
ACBH. Other Aquorthels that have less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Aquorthels
ACBI. Other Aquorthels that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Aquorthels
ACBJ. Other Aquorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Argiorthels
ACFA. Argiorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Argiorthels
ACFB. Other Argiorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Natric Argiorthels
ACFC. Other Argiorthels that have a natric horizon.
--------------------------
Typic Argiorthels
ACFD. Other Argiorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplorthels
ACHA. Haplorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Haplorthels
ACHB. Other Haplorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Haplorthels
ACHC. Other Haplorthels that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Folistic Haplorthels
ACHD. Other Haplorthels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquic Haplorthels
ACHE. Other Haplorthels that have, in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Fluventic Haplorthels
ACHF. Other Haplorthels that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Haplorthels
ACHG. Other Haplorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Historthels
ACAA. Historthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Historthels
ACAB. Other Historthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Historthels
ACAC. Other Historthels that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fluventic Historthels
ACAD. Other Historthels that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Ruptic Historthels
ACAE. Other Historthels that have more than 40 percent, by volume, organic soil materials from the soil surface to a depth of 50 cm in 75 percent or less of the pedon.
--------------------------
Typic Historthels
ACAF. Other Historthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Mollorthels
ACDA. Mollorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Mollorthels
ACDB. Other Mollorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Vertic Mollorthels
ACDC. Other Mollorthels that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time during normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Andic Mollorthels
ACDD. Other Mollorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Mollorthels
ACDE. Other Mollorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Folistic Mollorthels
ACDF. Other Mollorthels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Cumulic Mollorthels
ACDG. Other Mollorthels that have both:
- - 1. A mollic epipedon that is 40 cm or more thick with a texture class finer than loamy fine sand; and
- - 2. A slope of less than 25 percent.
--------------------------
Aquic Mollorthels
ACDH. Other Mollorthels that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Typic Mollorthels
ACDI. Other Mollorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Psammorthels
ACGA. Psammorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Psammorthels
ACGB. Other Psammorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Spodic Psammorthels
ACGC. Other Psammorthels that have a horizon 5 cm or more thick that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Typic Psammorthels
ACGD. Other Psammorthels.
--------------------------
Lithic Umbrorthels
ACEA. Umbrorthels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Umbrorthels
ACEB. Other Umbrorthels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Vertic Umbrorthels
ACEC. Other Umbrorthels that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time during normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Andic Umbrorthels
ACED. Other Umbrorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Umbrorthels
ACEE. Other Umbrorthels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Folistic Umbrorthels
ACEF. Other Umbrorthels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Cumulic Umbrorthels
ACEG. Other Umbrorthels that have both:
- - 1. An umbric epipedon that is 40 cm or more thick with a texture class finer than loamy fine sand; and
- - 2. A slope of less than 25 percent.
--------------------------
Aquic Umbrorthels
ACEH. Other Umbrorthels that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Typic Umbrorthels
ACEI. Other Umbrorthels.
--------------------------
Histoturbels
ABA. Turbels that have, in 30 percent or more of the pedon, more than 40 percent, by volume, organic soil materials from the soil surface to a depth of 50 cm which meet the saturation requirement for a histic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquiturbels
ABB. Other Turbels that have, within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Anhyturbels
ABC. Other Turbels that have anhydrous conditions.
--------------------------
Molliturbels
ABD. Other Turbels that have a mollic epipedon.
--------------------------
Umbriturbels
ABE. Other Turbels that have an umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Psammoturbels
ABF. Other Turbels that have less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Haploturbels
ABG. Other Turbels.
--------------------------
Lithic Anhyturbels
ABCA. Anhyturbels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Anhyturbels
ABCB. Other Anhyturbels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Petrogypsic Anhyturbels
ABCC. Other Anhyturbels that have a petrogypsic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Gypsic Anhyturbels
ABCD. Other Anhyturbels that have a gypsic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Nitric Anhyturbels
ABCE. Other Anhyturbels that have both of the following:
- - 1. A horizon 15 cm or more thick that has a nitrate concentration of 118 mmol(-)/L or more in a 1:5 soil:water extract; and
- - 2. The product of horizon thickness (in cm) times nitrate concentration [in mmol(-)/L] is 3,500 or more.
--------------------------
Salic Anhyturbels
ABCF. Other Anhyturbels that have a salic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Calcic Anhyturbels
ABCG. Other Anhyturbels that have a calcic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Anhyturbels
ABCH. Other Anhyturbels.
--------------------------
Lithic Aquiturbels
ABBA. Aquiturbels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Aquiturbels
ABBB. Other Aquiturbels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Sulfuric Aquiturbels
ABBC. Other Aquiturbels that have a sulfuric horizon or sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Ruptic-Histic Aquiturbels
ABBD. Other Aquiturbels that have either:
- - 1. Organic soil materials that are discontinuous at the surface; or
- - 2. Organic soil materials at the surface that change in thickness fourfold or more within a pedon.
--------------------------
Psammentic Aquiturbels
ABBE. Other Aquiturbels that have less than 35 percent (by volume) rock fragments and a texture class of loamy fine sand or coarser in all layers within the particle-size control section.
--------------------------
Typic Aquiturbels
ABBF. Other Aquiturbels.
--------------------------

ABGA. Haploturbels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------

--------------------------

ABGC. Other Haploturbels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquic Haploturbels
ABGD. Other Haploturbels that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Typic Haploturbels
ABGE. Other Haploturbels.
--------------------------
Lithic Histoturbels
ABAA. Histoturbels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------

--------------------------
Lithic Molliturbels

ABDB. Other Molliturbels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Vertic Molliturbels
ABDC. Other Molliturbels that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time during normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Andic Molliturbels
ABDD. Other Molliturbels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Molliturbels
ABDE. Other Molliturbels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Folistic Molliturbels
ABDF. Other Molliturbels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Cumulic Molliturbels
ABDG. Other Molliturbels that have both:
- - 1. A mollic epipedon that is 40 cm or more thick with a texture class finer than loamy fine sand; and
- - 2. A slope of less than 25 percent.
--------------------------
Aquic Molliturbels
ABDH. Other Molliturbels that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Typic Molliturbels
ABDI. Other Molliturbels.
--------------------------
Lithic Psammoturbels
ABFA. Psammoturbels that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Glacic Psammoturbels
ABFB. Other Psammoturbels that have a glacic layer within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Spodic Psammoturbels
ABFC. Other Psammoturbels that have a horizon 5 cm or more thick that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling 0.25 or more, and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more, and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Typic Psammoturbels

--------------------------
Lithic Umbriturbels
