--------------------------
Vertic Umbriturbels
ABEC. Other Umbriturbels that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time during normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Andic Umbriturbels
ABED. Other Umbriturbels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Umbriturbels
ABEE. Other Umbriturbels that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Folistic Umbriturbels
ABEF. Other Umbriturbels that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Cumulic Umbriturbels
ABEG. Other Umbriturbels that have both:
- - 1. An umbric epipedon that is 40 cm or more thick with a texture class finer than loamy fine sand; and
- - 2. A slope of less than 25 percent.
--------------------------
Aquic Umbriturbels
ABEH. Other Umbriturbels that have, in one or more horizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, distinct or prominent redox concentrations and also aquic conditions for some time during normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Typic Umbriturbels
ABEI. Other Umbriturbels.
--------------------------
Folists
BA. Histosols that are saturated with water for less than 30 cumulative days during normal years (and are not artificially drained).
--------------------------
Wassists
BB. Other Histosols that have a positive water potential at the soil surface for more than 21 hours of each day in all years.
--------------------------
Fibrists
BC. Other Histosols that:
- - 1. Have more thickness of fibric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - - a. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - - b. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; and
- - 2. Do not have a sulfuric horizon within 50 cm of the soil surface; and
- - 3. Do not have sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Saprists
BD. Other Histosols that have more thickness of sapric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Hemists
BE. Other Histosols.
--------------------------
Cryofibrists
BCA. Fibrists that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Sphagnofibrists
BCB. Other Fibrists in which Sphagnum fibers constitute three-fourths or more of the volume to either a depth of 90 cm from the soil surface or to a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, fragmental materials, or other mineral soil materials if at a depth of less than 90 cm.
--------------------------
Haplofibrists
BCC. Other Fibrists.
--------------------------
Hydric Cryofibrists
BCAA. Cryofibrists that have a layer of water within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryofibrists
BCAB. Other Cryofibrists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Cryofibrists
BCAC. Other Cryofibrists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
CHAPTER 10
BCAD. Other Cryofibrists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more Histosols
--------------------------
Sphagnic Cryofibrists
BCAE. Other Cryofibrists in which three-fourths or more of the fiber volume in the surface tier is derived from Sphagnum.
--------------------------
Typic Cryofibrists
BCAF. Other Cryofibrists.
--------------------------
Hydric Haplofibrists
BCCA. Haplofibrists that have a layer of water within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplofibrists
BCCB. Other Haplofibrists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Limnic Haplofibrists
BCCC. Other Haplofibrists that have one or more limnic layers with a total thickness of 5 cm or more within the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Haplofibrists
BCCD. Other Haplofibrists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Haplofibrists
BCCE. Other Haplofibrists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Hemic Haplofibrists
BCCF. Other Haplofibrists that have one or more layers of hemic and sapric materials with a total thickness of 25 cm or more in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Haplofibrists
BCCG. Other Haplofibrists.
--------------------------
Hydric Sphagnofibrists
BCBA. Sphagnofibrists that have a layer of water within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Lithic Sphagnofibrists
BCBB. Other Sphagnofibrists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Limnic Sphagnofibrists
BCBC. Other Sphagnofibrists that have one or more limnic layers with a total thickness of 5 cm or more within the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Sphagnofibrists
BCBD. Other Sphagnofibrists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Sphagnofibrists
BCBE. Other Sphagnofibrists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Hemic Sphagnofibrists
BCBF. Other Sphagnofibrists that have one or more layers of hemic and sapric materials with a total thickness of 25 cm or more in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Sphagnofibrists
BCBG. Other Sphagnofibrists.
--------------------------
Cryofolists
BAA. Folists that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Torrifolists
BAB. Other Folists that have an aridic (or torric) soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Ustifolists
BAC. Other Folists that have an ustic or xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Udifolists
BAD. Other Folists.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryofolists
BAAA. Cryofolists that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Cryofolists
BAAB. Other Cryofolists.
--------------------------
Lithic Torrifolists
BABA. Torrifolists that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Torrifolists
BABB. Other Torrifolists.
--------------------------
Lithic Udifolists
BADA. Udifolists that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------

BADB. Other Udifolists.
--------------------------
Lithic Ustifolists
BACA. Ustifolists that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Ustifolists
BACB. Other Ustifolists.
--------------------------
Sulfohemists
BEA. Hemists that have a sulfuric horizon within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Sulfihemists
BEB. Other Hemists that have sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Luvihemists
BEC. Other Hemists that have a horizon 2 cm or more thick in which humilluvic material constitutes one-half or more of the volume.
--------------------------
Cryohemists
BED. Other Hemists that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Haplohemists
BEE. Other Hemists.
--------------------------
Hydric Cryohemists
BEDA. Cryohemists that have a layer of water within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryohemists
BEDB. Other Cryohemists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Cryohemists
BEDC. Other Cryohemists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Cryohemists
BEDD. Other Cryohemists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Cryohemists
BEDE. Other Cryohemists.
--------------------------
Hydric Haplohemists
BEEA. Haplohemists that have a layer of water within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplohemists
BEEB. Other Haplohemists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Limnic Haplohemists
BEEC. Other Haplohemists that have one or more limnic layers with a total thickness of 5 cm or more within the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Haplohemists
BEED. Other Haplohemists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Haplohemists
BEEE. Other Haplohemists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fibric Haplohemists
BEEF. Other Haplohemists that have one or more layers of fibric materials with a total thickness of 25 cm or more in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Sapric Haplohemists
BEEG. Other Haplohemists that have one or more layers of sapric materials with a total thickness of 25 cm or more below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Haplohemists
BEEH. Other Haplohemists.
--------------------------
Typic Luvihemists
BECA. All Luvihemists (provisionally).
--------------------------
Terric Sulfihemists
BEBA. Sulfihemists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfihemists
BEBB. Other Sulfihemists.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfohemists
BEAA. All Sulfohemists (provisionally).
--------------------------
Sulfosaprists
BDA. Saprists that have a sulfuric horizon within 50 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Sulfisaprists
BDB. Other Saprists that have sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Cryosaprists
BDC. Other Saprists that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Haplosaprists
BDD. Other Saprists.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryosaprists
BDCA. Cryosaprists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Terric Cryosaprists
BDCB. Other Cryosaprists that have one or more limnic layers with a total thickness of 5 cm or more within the control section.Limnic CryosapristsBDCC. Other Cryosaprists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Cryosaprists
BDCD. Other Cryosaprists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Cryosaprists
BDCE. Other Cryosaprists.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplosaprists
BDDA. Haplosaprists that have a lithic contact at the lower boundary of the control section.
--------------------------
Limnic Haplosaprists
BDDB. Other Haplosaprists that have one or more limnic layers with a total thickness of 5 cm or more within the control section.
--------------------------
Halic Terric Haplosaprists
BDDC. Other Haplosaprists that have both:
- - 1. Throughout a layer 30 cm or thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, an electrical conductivity of 30 dS/m or more (1:1 soil:water) for 6 months or more during normal years; and
- - 2. A layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Halic Haplosaprists
BDDD. Other Haplosaprists that have, throughout a layer 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, an electrical conductivity of 30 dS/m or more (1:1 soil:water) for 6 months or more during normal years.
--------------------------
Terric Haplosaprists
BDDE. Other Haplosaprists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Haplosaprists
BDDF. Other Haplosaprists that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Have a total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 2. Have, within the organic soil materials, either one layer of mineral soil material 5 cm or more thick or two or more layers of mineral soil material of any thickness in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Hemic Haplosaprists
BDDG. Other Haplosaprists that have one or more layers of fibric or hemic materials with a total thickness of 25 cm or more in the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Haplosaprists
BDDH. Other Haplosaprists.
--------------------------
Terric Sulfisaprists
BDBA. Sulfisaprists that have a layer of mineral soil material 30 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the control section, below the surface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfisaprists
BDBB. Other Sulfisaprists.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfosaprists
BDAA. All Sulfosaprists (provisionally).
--------------------------
Frasiwassists
BBA. Wassists that have, in all horizons within 100 cm of the soil surface, an electrical conductivity of less than 0.2 dS/m in a 1:5 (soil:water), by volume, supernatant (not extract).
--------------------------
Sulfiwassists
BBB. Other Wassists that have a horizon or horizons, with a combined thickness of at least 15 cm within 50 cm of the soil surface, that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Haplowassists
BBC. Other Wassists.
--------------------------
Fibric Frasiwassists
BBAA. Frasiwassists that:
- - 1. Have more thickness of fibric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - - a. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - - b. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; and
- - 2. Do not have sulfidic materials within 100 cm of the soil surface.
--------------------------
Sapric Frasiwassists
BBAB. Other Frasiwassists that have more thickness of sapric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Frasiwassists
BBAC. Other Frasiwassists.
--------------------------
Sulfic Haplowassists
BBCA. Haplowassists that have a horizon or horizons, with a combined thickness of 15 cm within 100 cm of the soil surface, that contain sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Fibric Haplowassists
BBCB. Other Haplowassists that have more thickness of fibric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Sapric Haplowassists
BBCC. Other Haplowassists that have more thickness of sapric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Haplowassists
BBCD. Other Haplowassists.
--------------------------
Fibric Sulfiwassists
BBBA. Sulfiwassists that have more thickness of fibric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Sapric Sulfiwassists
BBBB. Other Sulfiwassists that have more thickness of sapric soil materials than any other kind of organic soil materials either:
- - 1. In the organic parts of the subsurface tier if there is no continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier; or
- - 2. In the combined thickness of the organic parts of the surface and subsurface tiers and there is a continuous layer of mineral soil material 40 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within the subsurface tier.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfiwassists
BBBC. Other Sulfiwassists.
--------------------------
Aquepts
KA. Inceptisols that have one or more of the following:
- - 1. In a layer above a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact or in a layer at a depth between 40 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is shallower, aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage) and one or more of the following:
- - - a. A histic epipedon; or
- - - b. A sulfuric horizon within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - - c. A layer directly under the epipedon, or within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, that has, on faces of peds or in the matrix if peds are absent, 50 percent or more chroma of either:
- - - - (1) 2 or less if there are redox concentrations; or
- - - - (2) 1 or less; or
- - - d. Within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, enough active ferrous iron to give a positive reaction to alpha,alpha-dipyridyl at a time when the soil is not being irrigated; or
- - 2. An exchangeable sodium percentage (ESP) of 15 or more (or a sodium adsorption ratio [SAR] of 13 or more) in half or more of the soil volume within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, a decrease in ESP (or SAR) values with increasing depth below 50 cm, and ground water within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for some time during the year.
--------------------------
Gelepts
KB. Other Inceptisols that have a gelic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Cryepts
KC. Other Inceptisols that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Ustepts
KD. Other Inceptisols that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xerepts
KE. Other Inceptisols that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Udepts
KF. Other Inceptisols.
--------------------------
Sulfaquepts
KAA. Aquepts that have a sulfuric horizon within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Petraquepts
KAB. Other Aquepts that have, within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more horizons in which plinthite or a cemented diagnostic horizon either forms a continuous phase or constitutes one-half or more of the volume.
--------------------------
Halaquepts
KAC. Other Aquepts that have either:
- - 1. A salic horizon; or
- - 2. In one or more horizons with a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, an exchangeable sodium percentage (ESP) of 15 or more (or a sodium adsorption ratio [SAR] of 13 or more) and a decrease in ESP (or SAR) values with increasing depth below 50 cm.
--------------------------
Fragiaquepts
KAD. Other Aquepts that have a fragipan within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Cryaquepts
KAE. Other Aquepts that have a gelic soil temperature regime.Gelaquepts, p. 177KAF. Other Aquepts that have a cryic soil temperature regime.
--------------------------
Vermaquepts
KAG. Other Aquepts that have, in one or more layers at least 25 cm thick (cumulative) within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface, 25 percent or more (by volume) recognizable bioturbation, such as filled animal burrows, wormholes, or casts.
--------------------------
Humaquepts
KAH. Other Aquepts that have a histic, melanic, mollic, or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Epiaquepts
KAI. Other Aquepts that have episaturation.
--------------------------
Endoaquepts
KAJ. Other Aquepts.
--------------------------
Sulfic Cryaquepts
KAFA. Cryaquepts that have, within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A sulfuric horizon; or
- - 2. A horizon 15 cm or more thick that has all of the characteristics of a sulfuric horizon, except that it has a pH value between 3.5 and 4.0 and does not have sulfide or other sulfur-bearing minerals; or
- - 3. Sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Histic Lithic Cryaquepts
KAFB. Other Cryaquepts that have both a histic epipedon and a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Lithic Cryaquepts
KAFC. Other Cryaquepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Vertic Cryaquepts
KAFD. Other Cryaquepts that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Histic Cryaquepts
KAFE. Other Cryaquepts that have a histic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquandic Cryaquepts
KAFF. Other Cryaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Cryaquepts
KAFG. Other Cryaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Humic Cryaquepts
KAFH. Other Cryaquepts that have both:
- - 1. Chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons at a depth between 15 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. A mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Aeric Cryaquepts
KAFI. Other Cryaquepts that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons at a depth between 15 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Humic Cryaquepts
KAFJ. Other Cryaquepts that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Cryaquepts
KAFK. Other Cryaquepts.
--------------------------
Sulfic Endoaquepts
KAJA. Endoaquepts that have, within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A sulfuric horizon; or
- - 2. A horizon 15 cm or more thick that has all of the characteristics of a sulfuric horizon, except that it has a pH value between 3.5 and 4.0 and does not have sulfide or other sulfur-bearing minerals; or
- - 3. Sulfidic materials.
--------------------------
Lithic Endoaquepts
KAJB. Other Endoaquepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Vertic Endoaquepts
KAJC. Other Endoaquepts that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aquandic Endoaquepts
KAJD. Other Endoaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluventic Endoaquepts
KAJE. Other Endoaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. In one or more horizons between the A or Ap horizon and a depth of 75 cm below the mineral soil surface, one of the following colors:
- - - a. Hue of 7.5YR or redder in 50 percent or more of the matrix; and
- - - - (1) If peds are present, either chroma of 2 or more on 50 percent or more of ped exteriors or no redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less in ped interiors; or
- - - - (2) If peds are absent, chroma of 2 or more in 50 percent or more of the matrix; or
- - - b. In 50 percent or more of the matrix, hue of 10YR or yellower; and either
- - - - (1) Both a color value, moist, and chroma of 3 or more; or
- - - - (2) Chroma of 2 or more if there are no redox concentrations; and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Endoaquepts
KAJF. Other Endoaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fragic Endoaquepts
KAJG. Other Endoaquepts that have fragic soil properties:
- - 1. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick.
--------------------------
Aeric Endoaquepts
KAJH. Other Endoaquepts that have, in one or more horizons between the A or Ap horizon and a depth of 75 cm below the mineral soil surface, one of the following colors:
- - 1. Hue of 7.5YR or redder in 50 percent or more of the matrix; and
- - - a. If peds are present, either chroma of 2 or more on 50 percent or more of ped exteriors or no redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less in ped interiors; or
- - - b. If peds are absent, chroma of 2 or more in 50 percent or more of the matrix; or
- - 2. In 50 percent or more of the matrix, hue of 10YR or yellower and either:
- - - a. Both a color value, moist, and chroma of 3 or more; or
- - - b. Chroma of 2 or more if there are no redox concentrations.
--------------------------
Humic Endoaquepts
KAJI. Other Endoaquepts that have both:
- - 1. A color value, moist, of 3 or less and a color value, dry, of 5 or less (crushed and smoothed sample) either throughout the upper 15 cm of the mineral soil (unmixed) or between the mineral soil surface and a depth of 15 cm after mixing; and
- - 2. A base saturation (by NH4OAc) of less than 50 percent in some part within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Mollic Endoaquepts
KAJJ. Other Endoaquepts that have a color value, moist, of 3 or less and a color value, dry, of 5 or less (crushed and smoothed sample) either throughout the upper 15 cm of the mineral soil (unmixed) or between the mineral soil surface and a depth of 15 cm after mixing.
--------------------------
Typic Endoaquepts
KAJK. Other Endoaquepts.
--------------------------
Vertic Epiaquepts
KAIA. Epiaquepts that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aquandic Epiaquepts
KAIB. Other Epiaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Epiaquepts
KAIC. Other Epiaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fragic Epiaquepts
KAID. Other Epiaquepts that have fragic soil properties either:
- - 1. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick.
--------------------------
Aeric Epiaquepts
KAIE. Other Epiaquepts that have, in one or more horizons between the A or Ap horizon and a depth of 75 cm below the mineral soil surface, one of the following colors:
- - 1. Hue of 7.5YR or redder in 50 percent or more of the matrix; and
- - - a. If peds are present, either chroma of 2 or more on 50 percent or more of ped exteriors or no redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less in ped interiors; or
- - - b. If peds are absent, chroma of 2 or more in 50 percent or more of the matrix; or
- - 2. In 50 percent or more of the matrix, hue of 10YR or yellower and either:
- - - a. Both a color value, moist, and chroma of 3 or more; or
- - - b. Chroma of 2 or more if there are no redox concentrations.
--------------------------
Humic Epiaquepts
KAIF. Other Epiaquepts that have both:
- - 1. A color value, moist, of 3 or less and a color value, dry, of 5 or less (crushed and smoothed sample) either throughout the upper 15 cm of the mineral soil (unmixed) or between the mineral soil surface and a depth of 15 cm after mixing; and
- - 2. A base saturation (by NH4OAc) of less than 50 percent in some part within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Mollic Epiaquepts
KAIG. Other Epiaquepts that have a color value, moist, of 3 or less and a color value, dry, of 5 or less (crushed and smoothed sample) either throughout the upper 15 cm of the mineral soil (unmixed) or between the mineral soil surface and a depth of 15 cm after mixing.
--------------------------
Typic Epiaquepts
KAIH. Other Epiaquepts.
--------------------------
Aeric Fragiaquepts
KADA. Fragiaquepts that have, in 50 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons either between the plow layer and a depth of 75 cm below the mineral soil surface or, if there is no plow layer, between depths of 15 and 75 cm, chroma of either:
- - 1. 3 or more; or
- - 2. 2 or more if there are no redox concentrations.
--------------------------
Humic Fragiaquepts
KADB. Other Fragiaquepts that have a histic, mollic, or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Fragiaquepts
KADC. Other Fragiaquepts.
--------------------------
Lithic Gelaquepts
KAEA. Gelaquepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Histic Gelaquepts
KAEB. Other Gelaquepts that have a histic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquandic Gelaquepts
KAEC. Other Gelaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Gelaquepts
KAED. Other Gelaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Humic Gelaquepts
KAEE. Other Gelaquepts that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Turbic Gelaquepts
KAEF. Other Gelaquepts that have gelic materials within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Gelaquepts
KAEG. Other Gelaquepts.
--------------------------
Vertic Halaquepts
KACA. Halaquepts that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aquandic Halaquepts
KACB. Other Halaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Duric Halaquepts
KACC. Other Halaquepts that have one or more horizons, with a combined thickness of 15 cm or more, that contain 20 percent or more (by volume) cemented soil material and are within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Halaquepts
KACD. Other Halaquepts that have chroma of 3 or more in 40 percent or more of the matrix of one or more horizons at a depth between 15 and 75 cm from the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Halaquepts
KACE. Other Halaquepts.
--------------------------
Hydraquentic Humaquepts
KAHA. Humaquepts that have an n value of either:
- - 1. More than 0.7 (and less than 8 percent clay) in one or more layers at a depth between 20 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. More than 0.9 in one or more layers at a depth between 50 and 100 cm.
--------------------------
Histic Humaquepts
KAHB. Other Humaquepts that have a histic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquandic Humaquepts
KAHC. Other Humaquepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Cumulic Humaquepts
KAHD. Other Humaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. An umbric or mollic epipedon that is 60 cm or more thick; and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Humaquepts
KAHE. Other Humaquepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Humaquepts
KAHF. Other Humaquepts that have hue of 5Y or redder and chroma of 3 or more in more than 40 percent of the matrix of one or more subhorizons at a depth between 15 and 75 cm from the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Humaquepts
KAHG. Other Humaquepts.
--------------------------
Histic Placic Petraquepts
KABA. Petraquepts that have both:
- - 1. A histic epipedon; and
- - 2. A placic horizon.
--------------------------
Placic Petraquepts
KABB. Other Petraquepts that have a placic horizon.
--------------------------
Plinthic Petraquepts
KABC. Other Petraquepts that have one or more horizons within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface in which plinthite either forms a continuous phase or constitutes one-half or more of the volume.
--------------------------
Typic Petraquepts
KABD. Other Petraquepts.
--------------------------
Salidic Sulfaquepts
KAAA. Sulfaquepts that have a salic horizon within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Hydraquentic Sulfaquepts
KAAB. Other Sulfaquepts that have an n value of either:
- - 1. More than 0.7 (and 8 or more percent clay) in one or more layers at a depth between 20 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. More than 0.9 in one or more layers at a depth between 50 and 100 cm from the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Sulfaquepts
KAAC. Other Sulfaquepts.
--------------------------
Sodic Vermaquepts
KAGA. Vermaquepts that have an exchangeable sodium percentage of 7 or more (or a sodium adsorption ratio [SAR] of 6 or more) in one or more subhorizons within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Vermaquepts
KAGB. Other Vermaquepts.
--------------------------
Humicryepts
KCA. Cryepts that have an umbric or mollic epipedon.
--------------------------
Calcicryepts
KCB. Other Cryepts that have a calcic or petrocalcic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Dystrocryepts
KCC. Other Cryepts that meet both of the following:
- - 1. Do not have free carbonates within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. Have a base saturation (by NH4OAc) of less than 50 percent, either:
- - - a. In one-half or more of the thickness between 25 and 75 cm below the mineral soil surface and there is no placic horizon, duripan, fragipan, or densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - - b. In a layer, 10 cm or more thick, directly above a placic horizon, duripan, fragipan, or densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Haplocryepts
KCD. Other Cryepts.
--------------------------
Lithic Calcicryepts
KCBA. Calcicryepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Calcicryepts
KCBB. Other Calcicryepts that in normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Xeric Calcicryepts
KCBC. Other Calcicryepts that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Ustic Calcicryepts
KCBD. Other Calcicryepts that are dry in some part of the moisture control section for 45 or more days (cumulative) in normal years.
--------------------------
Typic Calcicryepts
KCBE. Other Calcicryepts.
--------------------------
Lithic Dystrocryepts
KCCA. Dystrocryepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquandic Dystrocryepts
KCCB. Other Dystrocryepts that have both:
- - 1. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - - a. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more; or
- - - b. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - c. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Haploxerandic Dystrocryepts
KCCC. Other Dystrocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Vitrixerandic Dystrocryepts
KCCD. Other Dystrocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - - a. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - b. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Andic Dystrocryepts
KCCE. Other Dystrocryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Dystrocryepts
KCCF. Other Dystrocryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Dystrocryepts
KCCG. Other Dystrocryepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Folistic Dystrocryepts
KCCH. Other Dystrocryepts that have a folistic epipedon.
--------------------------
Aquic Dystrocryepts
KCCI. Other Dystrocryepts that have, in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Dystrocryepts
KCCJ. Other Dystrocryepts that in normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Lamellic Dystrocryepts
KCCK. Other Dystrocryepts that have lamellae (two or more) within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluventic Dystrocryepts
KCCL. Other Dystrocryepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Spodic Dystrocryepts
KCCM. Other Dystrocryepts that have a horizon 5 cm or more thick that has one or more of the following:
- - 1. In 25 percent or more of each pedon, cementation by organic matter and aluminum, with or without iron; or
- - 2. Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 0.25 percent or more and half that amount or less in an overlying horizon; or
- - 3. An ODOE value of 0.12 or more and a value half as high or lower in an overlying horizon.
--------------------------
Xeric Dystrocryepts
KCCN. Other Dystrocryepts that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Ustic Dystrocryepts
KCCO. Other Dystrocryepts that are dry in some part of the moisture control section for 45 or more days (cumulative) in normal years.
--------------------------
Eutric Dystrocryepts
KCCP. Other Dystrocryepts that have a base saturation (by NH4OAc) of 50 percent or more in one or more horizons between 25 and 50 cm from the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Dystrocryepts
KCCQ. Other Dystrocryepts.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplocryepts
KCDA. Haplocryepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquandic Haplocryepts
KCDB. Other Haplocryepts that have both:
- - 1. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - - a. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more; or
- - - b. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - c. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Haploxerandic Haplocryepts
KCDC. Other Haplocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Vitrixerandic Haplocryepts
KCDD. Other Haplocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - - a. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - b. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Haplustandic Haplocryepts
KCDE. Other Haplocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that is dry in some part for 45 or more days (cumulative) in normal years; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Ustivitrandic Haplocryepts
KCDF. Other Haplocryepts that have both:
- - 1. A moisture control section that is dry in some part for 45 or more days (cumulative) in normal years; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - - a. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - b. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Andic Haplocryepts
KCDG. Other Haplocryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Vitrandic Haplocryepts
KCDH. Other Haplocryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - 1. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Fluvaquentic Haplocryepts
KCDI. Other Haplocryepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 4. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aquic Haplocryepts
KCDJ. Other Haplocryepts that have, in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Haplocryepts
KCDK. Other Haplocryepts that in normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Lamellic Haplocryepts
KCDL. Other Haplocryepts that have lamellae (two or more) within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fluventic Haplocryepts
KCDM. Other Haplocryepts that have all of the following:
- - 1. A slope of less than 25 percent; and
- - 2. A total thickness of less than 50 cm of human-transported material in the surface horizons; and
- - 3. One or both of the following:
- - - a. At a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface, an organic-carbon content (Holocene age) of 0.2 percent or more and no densic, lithic, or paralithic contact within that depth; or
- - - b. An irregular decrease in organic-carbon content (Holocene age) between a depth of 25 cm and either a depth of 125 cm below the mineral soil surface or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Calcic Haplocryepts
KCDN. Other Haplocryepts that have identifiable secondary carbonates within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Xeric Haplocryepts
KCDO. Other Haplocryepts that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Ustic Haplocryepts
KCDP. Other Haplocryepts that are dry in some part of the moisture control section for 45 or more days (cumulative) in normal years.
--------------------------
Typic Haplocryepts
KCDQ. Other Haplocryepts.
--------------------------
Lithic Humicryepts
KCAA. Humicryepts that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquandic Humicryepts
KCAB. Other Humicryepts that have both:
- - 1. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - - a. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more; or
- - - b. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - c. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Haploxerandic Humicryepts
KCAC. Other Humicryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.
--------------------------
Vitrixerandic Humicryepts
KCAD. Other Humicryepts that have both:
- - 1. A xeric soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:
- - - a. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - - b. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - - (1) In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - - (2) [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.

Andic Humicryepts
KCAE. Other Humicryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus ½ Fe (by ammonium oxalate) of 1.0 percent or more.

Vitrandic Humicryepts
KCAF. Other Humicryepts that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or both of the following:

- - 2. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and

- - - b. [(Al plus ½ Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
