CBAA. Humigelods that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Andic Humigelods
CBAB. Other Humigelods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aquic Humigelods
CBAC. Other Humigelods that have redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Turbic Humigelods
CBAD. Other Humigelods that have gelic materials within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Humigelods
CBAE. Other Humigelods.
--------------------------
Placohumods
CDA. Humods that have a placic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in 50 percent or more of each pedon.
--------------------------
Durihumods
CDB. Other Humods that have, in 90 percent or more of each pedon, a cemented horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fragihumods
CDC. Other Humods that have a fragipan within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Haplohumods
CDD. Other Humods.
--------------------------
Andic Durihumods
CDBA. Durihumods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Durihumods
CDBB. Other Durihumods.
--------------------------
Typic Fragihumods
CDCA. All Fragihumods (provisionally).
--------------------------
Lithic Haplohumods
CDDA. Haplohumods that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Andic Haplohumods
CDDB. Other Haplohumods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Haploplaggic Haplohumods
CDDC. Other Haplohumods that have a surface horizon between 25 and 50 cm thick that meets all of the requirements for a plaggen epipedon except thickness.
--------------------------
Typic Haplohumods
CDDD. Other Haplohumods.
--------------------------
Andic Placohumods
CDAA. Placohumods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Placohumods
CDAB. Other Placohumods.
--------------------------
Placorthods
CEA. Orthods that have, in 50 percent or more of each pedon, a placic horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Durorthods
CEB. Other Orthods that have, in 90 percent or more of each pedon, a cemented horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fragiorthods
CEC. Other Orthods that have a fragipan within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Alorthods
CED. Other Orthods that have less than 0.10 percent iron
- - - - - (by ammonium oxalate) in 75 percent or more of the spodic horizon.
--------------------------
Haplorthods
CEE. Other Orthods.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Alorthods
CEDA. Alorthods that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Arenic Ultic Alorthods
CEDB. Other Alorthods that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a spodic horizon at a depth of 75 to 125 cm; and
- - 2. Have an argillic or kandic horizon below the spodic horizon.
--------------------------
Arenic Alorthods
CEDC. Other Alorthods that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a spodic horizon at a depth of 75 to 125 cm.
--------------------------
Entic Grossarenic Alorthods
CEDD. Other Alorthods that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a spodic horizon at a depth of 125 cm or more; and
- - 2. Have, in 10 percent or more of each pedon, less than 3.0 percent organic carbon in the upper 2 cm of the spodic horizon.
--------------------------
Entic Alorthods
CEDE. Other Alorthods that have, in 10 percent or more of each pedon, less than 3.0 percent organic carbon in the upper 2 cm of the spodic horizon.
--------------------------
Grossarenic Alorthods
CEDF. Other Alorthods that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a spodic horizon at a depth of 125 cm or more.
--------------------------
Haploplaggic Alorthods
CEDG. Other Alorthods that have a surface horizon between 25 and 50 cm thick that meets all of the requirements for a plaggen epipedon except thickness.
--------------------------
Alfic Alorthods
CEDH. Other Alorthods that have, within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part.
--------------------------
Ultic Alorthods
CEDI. Other Alorthods that have an argillic or kandic horizon within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Alorthods
CEDJ. Other Alorthods.
--------------------------
Andic Durorthods
CEBA. Durorthods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Typic Durorthods
CEBB. Other Durorthods.
--------------------------
Aquic Fragiorthods
CECA. Fragiorthods that have redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Alfic Oxyaquic Fragiorthods
CECB. Other Fragiorthods that:
- - 1. Are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days; and
- - 2. Have, within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Fragiorthods
CECC. Other Fragiorthods that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Haploplaggic Fragiorthods
CECD. Other Fragiorthods that have a surface horizon between 25 and 50 cm thick that meets all of the requirements for a plaggen epipedon except thickness.
--------------------------
Alfic Fragiorthods
CECE. Other Fragiorthods that have, within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part.
--------------------------
Ultic Fragiorthods
CECF. Other Fragiorthods that have an argillic or kandic horizon within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Entic Fragiorthods
CECG. Other Fragiorthods that have a spodic horizon that has one of the following:
- - 1. A texture class of very fine sand, loamy very fine sand, or finer and all of the following:
- - - a. A thickness of 10 cm or less; and
- - - b. A weighted average of less than 1.2 percent organic carbon; and
- - - c. Within the upper 7.5 cm, either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample); or
- - 2. A texture class of loamy fine sand, fine sand, or coarser and either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample) in the upper 2.5 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Fragiorthods
CECH. Other Fragiorthods.
--------------------------
Entic Lithic Haplorthods
CEEA. Haplorthods that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface and either:
- - 1. A spodic horizon with a texture class of very fine sand, loamy very fine sand, or finer and all of the following:
- - - a. A thickness of 10 cm or less; and
- - - b. A weighted average of less than 1.2 percent organic carbon; and
- - - c. Within the upper 7.5 cm, either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample); or
- - 2. A spodic horizon with a texture class of loamy fine sand, fine sand, or coarser and either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample) in the upper 2.5 cm.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplorthods
CEEB. Other Haplorthods that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Fragiaquic Haplorthods
CEEC. Other Haplorthods that have both:
- - 1. Fragic soil properties:
- - - a. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - - b. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick; and
- - 2. Redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Aqualfic Haplorthods
CEED. Other Haplorthods that have both:
- - 1. Redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part.
--------------------------
Aquentic Haplorthods
CEEE. Other Haplorthods that have redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage) and either:
- - 1. A spodic horizon with a texture class of very fine sand, loamy very fine sand, or finer and all of the following:
- - - a. A thickness of 10 cm or less; and
- - - b. A weighted average of less than 1.2 percent organic carbon; and
- - - c. Within the upper 7.5 cm, either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample); or
- - 2. A spodic horizon with a texture class of loamy fine sand, fine sand, or coarser and either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample) in the upper 2.5 cm.
--------------------------
Aquic Haplorthods
CEEF. Other Haplorthods that have redoximorphic features in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface and also aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Alfic Oxyaquic Haplorthods
CEEG. Other Haplorthods that have:
- - 1. Within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part; and
- - 2. Saturation with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Ultic Haplorthods
CEEH. Other Haplorthods that have:
- - 1. Within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon; and
- - 2. Saturation with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Fragic Haplorthods
CEEI. Other Haplorthods that have fragic soil properties either:
- - 1. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick.
--------------------------
Lamellic Oxyaquic Haplorthods
CEEJ. Other Haplorthods that have both:
- - 1. Saturation with water in 1 or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days; and
- - 2. Below the spodic horizon but not below an argillic horizon, lamellae (two or more) within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Lamellic Haplorthods
CEEK. Other Haplorthods that, below the spodic horizon but not below an argillic horizon, have lamellae (two or more) within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Haplorthods
CEEL. Other Haplorthods that are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface in normal years for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Andic Haplorthods
CEEM. Other Haplorthods that have andic soil properties throughout horizons that have a total thickness of 25 cm or more within 75 cm either of the mineral soil surface or of the top of an organic layer with andic soil properties, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Alfic Haplorthods
CEEN. Other Haplorthods that have, within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface, an argillic or kandic horizon that has a base saturation (by sum of cations) of 35 percent or more in some part.
--------------------------
Ultic Haplorthods
CEEO. Other Haplorthods that have an argillic or kandic horizon within 200 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Entic Haplorthods
CEEP. Other Haplorthods that have a spodic horizon that has one of the following:
- - 1. A texture class of very fine sand, loamy very fine sand, or finer and all of the following:
- - - a. A thickness of 10 cm or less; and
- - - b. A weighted average of less than 1.2 percent organic carbon; and
- - - c. Within the upper 7.5 cm, either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample); or
- - 2. A texture class of loamy fine sand, fine sand, or coarser and either or both a moist color value or chroma of 4 or more (crushed and smoothed sample) in the upper 2.5 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Haplorthods
CEEQ. Other Haplorthods.
--------------------------
Typic Placorthods
CEAA. All Placorthods (provisionally).
--------------------------
Aquults
HA. Ultisols that have aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage) in one or more horizons within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface and one or both of the following:
- - 1. Redoximorphic features in all layers between either the lower boundary of an Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 40 cm and one of the following within the upper 12.5 cm of the argillic or kandic horizon:
- - - a. Redox concentrations and 50 percent or more redox depletions with chroma of 2 or less either on faces of peds or in the matrix; or
- - - b. 50 percent or more redox depletions with chroma of 1 or less either on faces of peds or in the matrix; or
- - - c. Distinct or prominent redox concentrations and 50 percent or more hue of 2.5Y or 5Y in the matrix and also a thermic, isothermic, or warmer soil temperature regime; or
- - 2. Within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface, enough active ferrous iron to give a positive reaction to alpha,alpha-dipyridyl at a time when the soil is not being irrigated.
--------------------------
Humults
HB. Other Ultisols that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. 0.9 percent (by weighted average) or more organic carbon in the upper 15 cm of the argillic or kandic horizon; or
- - 2. 12 kg/m2 or more organic carbon between the mineral soil surface and a depth of 100 cm.
--------------------------
Udults
HC. Other Ultisols that have a udic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Ustults
HD. Other Ultisols that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xerults
HE. Other Ultisols.
--------------------------
Plinthaquults
HAA. Aquults that have one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in which plinthite either forms a continuous phase or constitutes one-half or more of the volume.
--------------------------
Fragiaquults
HAB. Other Aquults that have a fragipan within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Albaquults
HAC. Other Aquults that have an abrupt textural change between the ochric epipedon or albic horizon and the argillic or kandic horizon and have a saturated hydraulic conductivity of 0.4 cm/hr (1.0 µm/sec) or slower (moderately low or lower Ksat class) in the argillic or kandic horizon.
--------------------------
Kandiaquults
HAD. Other Aquults that:
- - 1. Do not have a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. Have a kandic horizon; and
- - 3. Within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, either:
- - - a. With increasing depth, do not have a clay decrease of 20 percent or more (relative) from the maximum clay content; or
- - - b. Have 5 percent or more (by volume) clay depletions on faces of peds in the layer that has a 20 percent lower clay content and, below that layer, a clay increase of 3 percent or more (absolute) in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Kanhaplaquults
HAE. Other Aquults that have a kandic horizon.
--------------------------
CHAPTER 15
HAF. Other Aquults that:
- - 1. Do not have a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. Within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, either:Ultisols
--------------------------
Umbraquults
HAG. Other Aquults that have an umbric or mollic epipedon.
--------------------------
Epiaquults
HAH. Other Aquults that have episaturation.
--------------------------
Endoaquults
HAI. Other Aquults.
--------------------------
Vertic Albaquults
HACA. Albaquults that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Kandic Albaquults
HACB. Other Albaquults that have a kandic horizon.
--------------------------
Aeric Albaquults
HACC. Other Albaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Albaquults
HACD. Other Albaquults.
--------------------------
Arenic Endoaquults
HAIA. Endoaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm.
--------------------------
Grossarenic Endoaquults
HAIB. Other Endoaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 100 cm or more.
--------------------------
Aeric Endoaquults
HAIC. Other Endoaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Endoaquults
HAID. Other Endoaquults.
--------------------------
Vertic Epiaquults
HAHA. Epiaquults that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Aeric Fragic Epiaquults
HAHB. Other Epiaquults that have both of the following:
- - 1. Fragic soil properties either:
- - - a. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - - b. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick; and
- - 2. 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Arenic Epiaquults
HAHC. Other Epiaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm.
--------------------------
Grossarenic Epiaquults
HAHD. Other Epiaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 100 cm or more.
--------------------------
Fragic Epiaquults
HAHE. Other Epiaquults that have fragic soil properties either:
- - 1. In 30 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. In 60 percent or more of the volume of a layer 15 cm or more thick.
--------------------------
Aeric Epiaquults
HAHF. Other Epiaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Epiaquults
HAHG. Other Epiaquults.
--------------------------
Aeric Fragiaquults
HABA. Fragiaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and the fragipan.
--------------------------
Plinthic Fragiaquults
HABB. Other Fragiaquults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Umbric Fragiaquults
HABC. Other Fragiaquults that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Fragiaquults
HABD. Other Fragiaquults.
--------------------------
Acraquoxic Kandiaquults
HADA. Kandiaquults that have an ECEC of 1.5 cmol(+)/kg clay or less (sum of bases extracted with 1N NH4OAc pH 7, plus 1N KCl-extractable Al) in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Arenic Plinthic Kandiaquults
HADB. Other Kandiaquults that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a kandic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm; and
- - 2. Have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Arenic Umbric Kandiaquults
HADC. Other Kandiaquults that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a kandic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm; and
- - 2. Have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Arenic Kandiaquults
HADD. Other Kandiaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a kandic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm.
--------------------------
Grossarenic Kandiaquults
HADE. Other Kandiaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of a kandic horizon at a depth of 100 cm or more.
--------------------------
Plinthic Kandiaquults
HADF. Other Kandiaquults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aeric Kandiaquults
HADG. Other Kandiaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Umbric Kandiaquults
HADH. Other Kandiaquults that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Kandiaquults
HADI. Other Kandiaquults.
--------------------------
Aquandic Kanhaplaquults
HAEA. Kanhaplaquults that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, one or more of the following:
- - 1. A fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; or
- - 2. More than 35 percent (by volume) particles 2.0 mm or larger in diameter, of which more than 66 percent is cinders, pumice, and pumicelike fragments; or
- - 3. A fine-earth fraction containing 30 percent or more particles 0.02 to 2.0 mm in diameter; and
- - - a. In the 0.02 to 2.0 mm fraction, 5 percent or more volcanic glass; and
- - - b. [(Al plus 1/2 Fe, percent extracted by ammonium oxalate) times 60] plus the volcanic glass (percent) is equal to 30 or more.
--------------------------
Plinthic Kanhaplaquults
HAEB. Other Kanhaplaquults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aeric Umbric Kanhaplaquults
HAEC. Other Kanhaplaquults that have both of the following:
- - 1. 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm; and
- - 2. A mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Aeric Kanhaplaquults
HAED. Other Kanhaplaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Umbric Kanhaplaquults
HAEE. Other Kanhaplaquults that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Kanhaplaquults
HAEF. Other Kanhaplaquults.
--------------------------
Vertic Paleaquults
HAFA. Paleaquults that have one or both of the following:
- - 1. Cracks within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface that are 5 mm or more wide through a thickness of 30 cm or more for some time in normal years and slickensides or wedge-shaped peds in a layer 15 cm or more thick that has its upper boundary within 125 cm of the mineral soil surface; or
- - 2. A linear extensibility of 6.0 cm or more between the mineral soil surface and either a depth of 100 cm or a densic, lithic, or paralithic contact, whichever is shallower.
--------------------------
Arenic Plinthic Paleaquults
HAFB. Other Paleaquults that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm; and
- - 2. Have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Arenic Umbric Paleaquults
HAFC. Other Paleaquults that:
- - 1. Have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm; and
- - 2. Have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Arenic Paleaquults
HAFD. Other Paleaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 50 to 100 cm.
--------------------------
Grossarenic Paleaquults
HAFE. Other Paleaquults that have a texture class (fine-earth fraction) of coarse sand, sand, fine sand, loamy coarse sand, loamy sand, or loamy fine sand throughout a layer extending from the mineral soil surface to the top of an argillic horizon at a depth of 100 cm or more.
--------------------------
Plinthic Paleaquults
HAFF. Other Paleaquults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aeric Paleaquults
HAFG. Other Paleaquults that have 50 percent or more chroma of 3 or more in one or more horizons between either the A or Ap horizon or a depth of 25 cm from the mineral soil surface, whichever is deeper, and a depth of 75 cm.
--------------------------
Umbric Paleaquults
HAFH. Other Paleaquults that have a mollic or umbric epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Paleaquults
HAFI. Other Paleaquults.
--------------------------
Kandic Plinthaquults
HAAA. Plinthaquults that have a kandic horizon or a CEC (by 1N NH4OAc pH 7) of less than 24 cmol(+)/kg clay in 50 percent or more (by volume) of the argillic horizon if less than 100 cm thick or of its upper 100 cm.
--------------------------
Typic Plinthaquults
HAAB. Other Plinthaquults.
--------------------------
Plinthic Umbraquults
HAGA. Umbraquults that have 5 to 50 percent (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Typic Umbraquults
HAGB. Other Umbraquults.
--------------------------
Sombrihumults
HBA. Humults that have a sombric horizon within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Plinthohumults
HBB. Other Humults that have one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface in which plinthite either forms a continuous phase or constitutes one-half or more of the volume.
--------------------------
Kandihumults
HBC. Other Humults that:
- - 1. Do not have a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. Have a kandic horizon; and
- - 3. Within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, either:
- - - a. With increasing depth, do not have a clay decrease of 20 percent or more (relative) from the maximum clay content; or
- - - b. Have 5 percent or more (by volume) skeletans on faces of peds in the layer that has a 20 percent lower clay content and, below that layer, a clay increase of 3 percent or more (absolute) in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Kanhaplohumults
HBD. Other Humults that have a kandic horizon.
--------------------------
Palehumults
HBE. Other Humults that:
- - 1. Do not have a densic, lithic, paralithic, or petroferric contact within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. Within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface, either:
- - - a. With increasing depth, do not have a clay decrease of 20 percent or more (relative) from the maximum clay content; or
- - - b. Have 5 percent or more (by volume) skeletans on faces of peds in the layer that has a 20 percent lower clay content and, below that layer, a clay increase of 3 percent or more (absolute) in the fine-earth fraction.
--------------------------
Haplohumults
HBF. Other Humults.
--------------------------
Lithic Haplohumults
HBFA. Haplohumults that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Aquandic Haplohumults
HBFB. Other Haplohumults that have both of the following:
- - 1. In one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the argillic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Aquic Haplohumults
HBFC. Other Haplohumults that have, in one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the argillic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Andic Haplohumults
HBFD. Other Haplohumults that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Plinthic Haplohumults
HBFE. Other Haplohumults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Oxyaquic Haplohumults
HBFF. Other Haplohumults that in normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Ustic Haplohumults
HBFG. Other Haplohumults that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xeric Haplohumults
HBFH. Other Haplohumults that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Typic Haplohumults
HBFI. Other Haplohumults.
--------------------------
Andic Ombroaquic Kandihumults
HBCA. Kandihumults that meet all of the following:
- - 1. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, have a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; and
- - 2. In one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, have redox concentrations, a color value, moist, of 4 or more, and hue that is 10YR or yellower and becomes redder with increasing depth within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 3. In normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Ustandic Kandihumults
HBCB. Other Kandihumults that have both of the following:
- - 1. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0; and
- - 2. An ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Andic Kandihumults
HBCC. Other Kandihumults that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Aquic Kandihumults
HBCD. Other Kandihumults that have, in one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the kandic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Ombroaquic Kandihumults
HBCE. Other Kandihumults that:
- - 1. Have, in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox concentrations, a color value, moist, of 4 or more, and hue that is 10YR or yellower and becomes redder with increasing depth within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. In normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Plinthic Kandihumults
HBCF. Other Kandihumults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Ustic Kandihumults
HBCG. Other Kandihumults that have an ustic soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Xeric Kandihumults
HBCH. Other Kandihumults that have a xeric soil moisture regime.
--------------------------
Anthropic Kandihumults
HBCI. Other Kandihumults that have an anthropic epipedon.
--------------------------
Typic Kandihumults
HBCJ. Other Kandihumults.
--------------------------
Lithic Kanhaplohumults
HBDA. Kanhaplohumults that have a lithic contact within 50 cm of the mineral soil surface.
--------------------------
Ustandic Kanhaplohumults
HBDB. Other Kanhaplohumults that have both of the following:
- - 1. An ustic soil moisture regime; and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Andic Kanhaplohumults
HBDC. Other Kanhaplohumults that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Aquic Kanhaplohumults
HBDD. Other Kanhaplohumults that have, in one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the kandic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Ombroaquic Kanhaplohumults
HBDE. Other Kanhaplohumults that:
- - 1. Have, in one or more horizons within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, redox concentrations, a color value, moist, of 4 or more, and hue that is 10YR or yellower and becomes redder with increasing depth within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface; and
- - 2. In normal years are saturated with water in one or more layers within 100 cm of the mineral soil surface for either or both:
- - - a. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - - b. 30 or more cumulative days.
--------------------------
Ustic Kanhaplohumults
HBDF. Other Kanhaplohumults that have an ustic soil moisture regime.

Xeric Kanhaplohumults

Typic Kanhaplohumults
HBDI. Other Kanhaplohumults.
--------------------------
Aquandic Palehumults
HBEA. Palehumults that have both of the following:
- - 1. In one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the argillic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage); and
- - 2. Throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Andic Palehumults
HBEB. Other Palehumults that have, throughout one or more horizons with a total thickness of 18 cm or more within 75 cm of the mineral soil surface, a fine-earth fraction with both a bulk density of 1.0 g/cm3 or less, measured at 33 kPa water retention, and Al plus 1/2 Fe percentages (by ammonium oxalate) totaling more than 1.0.
--------------------------
Aquic Palehumults
HBEC. Other Palehumults that have, in one or more subhorizons within the upper 25 cm of the argillic horizon, redox depletions with a color value, moist, of 4 or more and chroma of 2 or less, accompanied by both redox concentrations and aquic conditions for some time in normal years (or artificial drainage).
--------------------------
Plinthic Palehumults
HBED. Other Palehumults that have 5 percent or more (by volume) plinthite in one or more horizons within 150 cm of the mineral soil surface.

- - 1. 20 or more consecutive days; or
- - 2. 30 or more cumulative days.
